brief_description of the content in the: The source page describes a rule that checks for syntax errors and unused URI templates in @Path annotations in RESTful Web Services.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'incorrect-path-uri-template' checks all classes in the project. If a class has the '@Path' annotation, it retrieves the value of the annotation. If the value is not empty, it asserts that the path exists. If the path does not exist, it generates a message indicating the incorrect or unused @Path URI template and the fully qualified name of the class.
PRE_model_validation: The rule uses only the built-in functions provided, and it follows the syntax of the Rule-Specific Language (RSL). It checks for the existence of a path specified in the @Path annotation, which is relevant to the topic of incorrect @Path URI templates.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. https://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/ws/rs/Path.html - This page from Oracle's official Java documentation explains the @Path annotation in JAX-RS. It provides details on how the annotation should be used, which is relevant to the rule that checks for incorrect usage of the annotation.
2. https://www.baeldung.com/jax-rs-path-annotation - This tutorial from Baeldung provides examples of how to use the @Path annotation in JAX-RS. It also explains how the annotation works, which is relevant to understanding the rule that checks for incorrect @Path URI templates.
